conclusion: The velocity-time graph shows how the velocity of an object changes over time. The slope of the graph at any point gives the acceleration of the object at that instant.
Linear motion means the object is moving in a straight line.
Gradually decreasing acceleration implies that the acceleration is becoming smaller over time, but it's still in the same direction.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity is positive, but the curve is leveling off.

premise: The curve is leveling off from 1 to 2 seconds.
conclusion: The acceleration is decreasing over this interval.
Red tangent lines show the slope is steeper at earlier times and less steep as time progresses towards 2 seconds.

premise: The slope is steeper at earlier times and less steep as time progresses towards 2 seconds.
conclusion: The acceleration is decreasing during this period.
At t=1 second, the velocity is around 20 m/s, and at t=2 seconds, it's around 15 m/s.

premise: The velocity decreases from 20 m/s to 15 m/s from t=1 to t=2 seconds.
conclusion: The acceleration is negative during this time.

premise: The velocity is positive throughout, but the slope (acceleration) changes sign.
conclusion: From t=1 to t=2 seconds, the acceleration is negative because the velocity is decreasing.

premise: Acceleration is negative from t=1 to t=2 seconds.
conclusion: The statement 'linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration' is incorrect.
